answers.answerText: A. Disruption of the ellipsoid zone
C. Atrophy of the right temporal macula
answers.explanation:
Using the left eye OCT macula as a control, one can appreciate the loss of neurosensory retinal tissue in the right eye macula, most notably temporal to the fovea (blue arrow). The ellipsoid zone, which is the hyper-reflective line just anterior to the RPE, is in-tact. There is no sign of pseudo-drusen at the level of the RPE or vitreomacular traction in the pre-retinal space.

![](/content/media/neuro_ophth_29_3.webp)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the main finding in the OCT macula images above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
Due to the findings on the right eye OCT macula, OCT ONH/RNFL imaging was conducted and is shown below:

![](/content/media/neuro_ophth_29_5.webp)

What is the main finding in the OCT ONH/RNFL above?

answers.explanation:
The OCT RNFL demonstrates a thin average RNFL thickness in the right eye (65µm) compared to the left eye (78µm). Using the RNFL thickness map and RNFL thickness plot, one can appreciate marked reduction in the thickness of the right nerve fibre layer, more so inferiorly than superiorly (purple arrows).

![](/content/media/neuro_ophth_29_6.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
Based on the OCT macula and RNFL images, the fundus photos were reviewed again. When coursing through the vessels emanating off the nerve, there was subtle attenuation of an arteriole branching off the inferior arcade.

Based on the patient presentation, fundus findings and OCT imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation: The patient presents with severe thinning of the temporal inner retina which corresponds to an attenuated inferotemporal retinal arteriole in the right eye.  He also presents with marked reduction of the inferotemporal RNFL thickness. Therefore, this patient most likely had an old branch retinal artery occlusion! As BRAOs are almost always secondary to thromboembolic events, a CT angiography from the aortic arch to the vertex should be ordered to rule out an embolic source. The patient’s family physician should also be engaged to help optimize any vascular risk factors.

title: Case 29
description: 73M presenting with decreased vision OD for 3 years
patientPresentation:
A 73-year-old man with no past medical or ocular history was referred to a neuro-ophthalmology clinic for decreased vision in his right eye. He noticed this decreased vision OD 3 years ago but denied any acute vision change or trauma. The vision was described as a “haze” that was worse in the superonasal quadrant OD. He denied GCA symptoms. He denied a painful red eye, flashes, floaters or visual field deficit.

On examination, visual acuity was 20/60 OD and 20/20 OS. There was no RAPD and intraocular pressure was normal. Extraocular motility and colour vision were normal. Anterior segment examination demonstrated symmetric 1+ nuclear sclerotic cataracts OU. Fundus photographs were taken and are shown below:

![](/content/media/neuro_ophth_29_1.webp)

Fundus examination, as shown above, showed a normal optic nerve and macula OU. OCT macula imaging was then performed and is shown below:
